A ring $R$ is called a principal ideal domain if it is an integral domain and every ideal of $R$ is principal.

An ideal \(\mathfrak{a}\) in a ring \(R\) is called reduced if \(\mathfrak{a} = \operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\), where \(\operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\) is the set of all elements \(a \in R\) such that there exists some \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(a^{n} \in \mathfrak{a}\).
Does the concept of a/an Principal Ideal Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Reduced ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a reduced ideal involves the concept of the radical of an ideal, which is defined independently of the structure of the ring being a Principal Ideal Domain (PID). The radical of an ideal \\(\mathfrak{a}\\) in a ring \\(R\\) is the set of all elements \\(a \\in R\\) such that there exists some \\(n \\in \mathbb{N}\\) with \\(a^n \\in \mathfrak{a}\\). This definition does not require the ring \\(R\\) to be a PID, nor does it rely on every ideal being principal. A PID is a specific type of ring where every ideal is principal and the ring itself is an integral domain, but these properties are not necessary to define or understand the concept of a reduced ideal. Therefore, the concept of a PID is not needed for the definition of a reduced ideal to make sense.
